content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

To determine the value of the solubility product constant, <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math>, a student prepares a saturated solution by dissolving <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><mpadded><msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow></mpadded></mpadded></math> in water. The <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression is <math alttext="K s p equals, the molar concentration of B a with a positive 2 charge, times the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msup><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Ba</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

(a) Write the balanced equation for the dissociation reaction that is consistent with the <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

To determine the value of the solubility product constant, <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math>, a student prepares a saturated solution by dissolving <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><mpadded><msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow></mpadded></mpadded></math> in water. The <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression is <math alttext="K s p equals, the molar concentration of B a with a positive 2 charge, times the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge, squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msup><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Ba</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

(a) Write the balanced equation for the dissociation reaction that is consistent with the <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression.

(b) The student determines that the solubility of <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> is <math alttext="18.5 grams per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18.5</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>g/L</mtext></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.

(i) Calculate the molar solubility of <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> in <math alttext="moles per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mol/L</mtext></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.

(ii) Calculate the value of <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> for <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></math>.

(c) The student creates a saturated solution of <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in water, as shown in the diagram. The student claims that the amount of undissolved <math alttext="B a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ba</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> will decrease when <math alttext="H N O 3, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is added. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer with a comparison of <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> and <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math>.

skill.text: 5.E: Determine a balanced chemical equation for a given chemical phenomenon.
